Review: A complex and multilayered natural-processed Ethiopia cup: fruit-forward with floral, aromatic wood, citrus and cocoa intrigue.

Name: Andi Sumatra
Review: This Sumatra cup has an especially vivacious mouthfeel, supporting notes of date-like fruit, sweet florals and nuts.

Name: Las Gravilias Costa Rica
Origin: Canton de Desamparados, San Jose, Costa Rica
Review: A crisply bright Costa Rica cup animated by pretty stone fruit and spicy floral notes.

Name: Nicaragua La Huella Catuaí
Review: A stone fruit- and floral-driven Nicaragua cup with an especially plush, vibrant mouthfeel.

Name: El Salvador Santa Elena Pacamara
Review: A nuanced, multi-layered Pacamara from El Salvador with enticing notes of spice, fruit, and rich florals, all adding up to a vibrantly high-toned cup.

Name: Guatemala Carlos Rivas
Review: A particularly chocolaty Guatemala coffee with an intriguing savory undertone akin to cumin that anchors and balances the cup’s deep sweetness.

Name: El Salvador Finca Kilimanjaro
Review: A roast leaning toward the dark end of medium encourages the chocolate and floral notes of this El Salvador produced by the celebrated Aida Batlle.

Name: Guatemala Bella Carmona
Review: A crisply sweet, nuanced, quietly complete Guatemala cup.

Name: Mexico Mayan Village Women’s Lot
Review: A quietly intricate Chiapas cup with an especially vivacious, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel.

Name: Honduras Finca Don Eusebio
Review: A sweetly and gently pungent, quietly rich, balanced Honduras cup.

Name: El Salvador Finca Las Duanas
Review: A harmonious El Salvador Pacamara cup with equal parts high-toned sweetness and deep-toned savory notes.

Name: El Salvador Las Mercedes La Avila
Origin: Tecapa Chinameca growing region, El Salvador
Review: A satisfyingly chocolaty El Salvador cup complicated by layers of floral and sweet herb notes.

Name: Guatemala El Plan Rosma
Review: Deeply chocolaty Guatemala cup with distinct tamarind and aromatic orchid notes leaning toward the tropical.

Name: Guatemala Bella Carmona
Review: An elegantly fruit-toned Guatemala cup with intimations of candied violets and almond brittle-like depth.

Name: Olvin Valle Honduras
Review: Brightly fruit-forward: distinct berry notes, rich-toned citrus zest and aromatic wood.

Name: Honduras
Review: A pretty Honduras cup with deeply sweet nut tones, delicate florals and citrusy herb notes.

Name: Honduras San Vincent
Review: A balanced cup redolent of Nutella (chocolate and hazelnut spread) with particularly lively mouthfeel.

Name: Tarrazu Asocafé Canet
Review: A zesty-sweet floral, chocolaty and citrusy Costa Rica cup.

Name: Ethiopia Sheka Kawo Kamina Natural
Review: Impressively balanced for all its citrusy leanings, this lovely natural-processed Ethiopia cup has layers of nuance — flowers, fruit, cocoa, in particular.

Name: Kona Champagne Natural Black Rock Farm
Review: An elegant wine-yeast-fermented natural-processed Kona cup with heady aromatics and lilting acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Uraga
Review: A washed-process Ethiopia cup with leading notes of stone fruit and spicy florals and an appealingly bright structure.

Name: Costa Rica Perla Negra
Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela growing region, Costa Rica
Review: A berry-centered natural-process Costa Rica cup with delicate cocoa, floral and aromatic wood notes.

Name: Indonesia Lintong Mandheling
Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia
Review: A fine example of a traditional Sumatra cup: viscous, juicy, aromatically driven by deep, earth-toned fruit and dry chocolate.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Bensa Natural Single-Variety Kurume G1
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A balanced, engaging natural-processed Ethiopia cup characterized by cocoa-toned fruit and rich florals.

Name: Costa Rica La Pastora
Origin: Santa Maria de Dota, Costa Rica
Review: A deep, nuanced washed-process Costa Rica cup with an especially viscous yet lively mouthfeel.

Name: Papua New Guinea “Papa Kinne”
Origin: Purosa Village, Eastern Highlands, Papua New Guinea
Review: A sweetly nut-toned, inviting PNG cup.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural Farm Direct
Review: A deep, delicately fruit-toned cup with ringing notes of dark chocolate throughout and citrusy undercurrents.

Name: Kenya Karatina AA 2020
Review: A bright, juicy Kenya cup with citrusy acidity: sweet, tart, floral and caramelly all at once.

Name: Colombia San Luís Gesha
Review: A delicate, confident honey-processed Colombia Gesha: balanced, bright, floral- and fruit-toned.

Name: Karani Kenya
Review: An alluring Kenya cup with classic red fruit and dark chocolate notes in harmony. Particularly plush mouthfeel.

Name: Miraflores Colombia
Review: A rich, juicy, exhilarating Colombia cup: sweetly tart with herb-toned floral and resonant cocoa notes.

Name: Kenya Gatuya
Review: A big, juicy, classic Kenya cup with distinct black currant notes characteristic of the origin, deep tones of dark chocolate throughout, and two differing floral tones, one savory (hop flowers) and one sweet (jasmine).

Name: Kenya Gicherori
Review: A nuanced, juicy, high-toned Kenya cup expressing admired and classic descriptors associated with the origin, including hallmark black currant and spice-toned, jasmine-like flowers.

Name: Ethiopia Duromina Agaro Gera
Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Review: A particularly fruit-centered washed-process Ethiopia cup, tropical leaning in its aromatics with a mysterious and pretty note of sandalwood running throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Kayon Mountain (Natural)
Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, southern Ethiopia
Review: A fruit and flower extravaganza; this clean natural-processed cup offers an abundance of berry, sweet floral, and dark chocolate notes, all in balance and lucidly expressed.

Name: Peru San Ignacio Calazobo Lot 2 FTO
Review: A welcoming, balanced, richly sweet Peru with a lilting throughline of milk chocolate; particularly satisfying mouthfeel and gentle acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Kayon Mountain (Washed)
Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, southern Ethiopia
Review: A delicate, confident, multi-layered Ethiopia cup that delivers stone fruit, deep florals, and juicy-bright acidity.

Name: Sahara Sunrise
Review: An easygoing, comfortable Rwanda cup characterized by nut-toned cocoa and crisp pear notes.

Name: Amazon Haze
Review: A darker-roasted Guatemala cup that foregrounds notes of lightly scorched aromatic wood and sweet cocoa powder.

Name: Organic Peru
Review: A friendly, balanced cup that leads with chocolate and nut tones, crisply sweet with floral undertones.

Name: Organic Sumatra
Review: A classic Sumatra cup, with deep sweetness and rich earth in balance, darker-roasted to bring out the chocolate notes.

Name: Organic Mexico
Review: A pleasing Chiapas cup, floral-driven with ballast from suggestions of cocoa and aromatic wood.

Name: Ethiopia Dame Dabaye
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Southern Ethiopia
Review: An exquisitely balanced washed-process Ethiopia cup with leading notes of delicate but deep florals, ripe stone fruit and a richly sweet herb tones.

Name: Ethiopia Suke Quto
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A cleanly fruit-forward natural-process Ethiopia cup with a particularly full yet lively mouthfeel.

Name: Gelena Abaya Natural
Review: A straight-ahead natural-process Yirgacheffe with classic blueberry top notes and pleasing chocolate undertones.

Name: Kenya Nyeri AB Nyeshun
Review: A balanced yet supremely intricate Kenya cup that hits all the notes: tropical fruit, deep chocolate, both savory and sweet florals, and a distinct wild honey.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Bishala
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Review: An elegant, floral-driven washed-process Ethiopia cup that presents in the cup with quiet confidence.

Name: Ethiopia Wegida Natural
Review: A very balanced, clean natural-processed Ethiopia with a sweetly herb- and stone fruit-driven palate; exceptionally pretty, plush mouthfeel.

Name: Organic Panorama
Review: A vibrant, richly sweet Ethiopia driven by deep floral and chocolate notes throughout.

Name: Organic Heartstrings
Review: A gently fruit-toned cup supported by spice-toned florals and rich dark chocolate suggestions.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Chelbessa Danche
Review: A friendly, accessible Ethiopia cup with pleasing cocoa notes throughout, complicated by stone fruit and aromatic wood.

Name: Ka’u Red Caturra Peaberry
Origin: Wood Valley, Ka’u, Big Island of Hawai’i
Review: An umami undercurrent (think candycap mushroom) deepens this already rich, stone fruit- and cocoa-driven cup.

Name: Ka’u Red Caturra
Origin: Wood Valley, Ka’u, Big Island of Hawai’i
Review: A balanced, vibrantly layered Ka’u cup with cocoa nib and honeysuckle-like flowers as throughlines.

Name: French Riviera
Review: A darker-roasted blend for those who prefer gentle acidity and a chocolate-toned cup.

Name: Wush Wush Ginbo Keffa Ethiopia
Review: So headily perfumed that this Ethiopia Wush Wush reads like dessert, redolent with more fruit tones than we can name, enveloped by a rich milk chocolate.

Name: Burundi Karehe
Review: A robust, complex, multilayered Burundi cup with lavish tropical fruit notes, deep dark chocolate, and bittersweet citrus zest impulses. Particularly juicy acidity.

Name: Colombia Finca El Roblar
Review: A nuanced, voluptuous Colombia cup with distinct notes of stone fruit, dark chocolate, and complex peppercorn tones: balanced, bright, juicy, deep.

Name: Limu Ethiopia Natural
Review: A delightful fruit bomb of a coffee with an intriguing lactic acid note, perhaps due to processing: deeply sweet, richly aromatic, and compellingly original.

Name: Estelí Nicaragua
Review: A big, confident Maracaturra cup from Nicaragua with nuanced savory notes underpinning richly sweet fruit and herb leanings.

Name: Ethiopia Gera Estate Natural
Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia Region, Ethiopia
Review: Subtle aromatics build in intensity toward a juicy, elegant cup with an especially attractive berry-toned finish.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Natural
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Southern Ethiopia
Review: A friendly natural-processed Ethiopia cup with a fruit-centered character balanced by deep, creamy nut tones and lively lime zest.

Name: Ka’u Classic Medium Roast
Origin: Ka'u growing district, "Big Island" of Hawai’i
Review: A classic Typica profile — nuanced, balanced and quietly complex — with notes of stone fruit, chocolate and an intriguing whisper of pipe tobacco.

Name: Safari Blend
Review: A sweet, high-toned Kenya cup driven by notes of stone fruit and cocoa nib, anchored by a black tea-like suggestion.

Name: East Fourteenth
Review: A deftly darker-roasted Tanzania cup, profiled to bring out the inherent dark chocolate potential of the green coffee, but without introducing woody or roasty notes.

Name: Kenya Kapsakiso
Review: A friendly, inviting Kenya cup: chocolaty and berry-driven with especially vibrant acidity.

Name: Jacmel Haiti
Review: A gentle, sweetly nut-toned coffee from the underrepresented origin of Haiti. Quietly lovely.

Name: Indonesian Sumatra Blend
Review: A nuanced, multi-layered Sumatra blend that plays sweet-savory and spice-toned off richly earthy: a friendly, accessible, classic Sumatra cup.

Name: Colombia Huila Geisha Las Mieles
Review: An accessible honey-processed Colombia Geisha with notes of chocolate and baking spices as pleasing throughline.

Name: Costa Rica Coffea Diversa Washed Geisha
Review: A lovely Geisha grown in Costa Rica deftly roasted to highlight  bright fruit and sweet floral tones.

Name: Guatemala Bella Carmona
Review: A paradoxically deep (chocolaty) and bright (stone fruit-toned) Guatemala cup that achieves a complex yet harmonious balance. Richly floral as well.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Debo
Review: A floral-driven washed-process Ethiopia cup: bright, nimble, juicy, and flavor-saturated.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Natural Water-Processed Decaf
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Southern Ethiopia
Review: A fine decaf cup that displays much of the sweetness and florality associated with its admired origin, the Guji Zone of southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kilauea Volcano Champagne Natural
Origin: Volcano, Puna District, Big Island of Hawai’i
Review: An experimentally processed coffee that is as lively as its name implies, both in terms of its high-toned fruit profile and its Champagne-like (sparkling, phosphoric) acidity.

Name: Nicaragua La Benedicion SL28 Natural
Review: Interesting for several reasons: variety (Kenya’s famous SL28), origin (Nicaragua) and processing method (dried-in-the-fruit or natural) — a trifecta of compelling reasons to experience this innovative coffee.

Name: Colombia Tolima Geisha
Review: A complex, original washed-process Colombia Geisha that hits all of the celebrated Geisha notes: stonefruit, sweet flowers, gentle spice notes, crisp cocoa.

Name: Galapagos La Tortuga
Origin: Isla Santa Cruz and Isla San Cristóbal, Galapagos Islands, Ecuador
Review: A delicate, intriguing, richly sweet cup from the famous Galapagos Islands.

Name: South Africa Elephant Coast Estate Coffea Racemosa
Review: While basically sweet, this coffee’s main impulses are a unique and intriguing citrus-zest-like bittersweetness with savory floral underpinnings.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Hambela Buku Abel Natural G1
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Southern Ethiopia
Review: A cleanly fruit-toned natural-processed Ethiopia cup with prominent berry and chocolate notes throughout and a particularly full mouthfeel.

Name: Ethiopia Haro Guta Natural
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Review: Delicately fruit-forward, intricately balanced, berry and cocoa-driven with bright, juicy acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Harfusa G1
Review: A quietly engaging washed Ethiopia cup with juicy acidity and sweet spice tones as a compelling throughline.

Name: Kenya AA Kirinyaga Kii
Review: A fine version of the classic Kenya cup: deep-toned, richly bittersweet, cocoa- and currant-driven.

Name: Colombia Antioquia La Papaya Bourbon Chiroso
Review: A washed Colombia cup redolent of high-quality chocolate, supported by delicate, sweet wisteria-like flowers.

Name: Ethiopia Gatame Muka Natural
Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A vivacious, bright, fruit-toned natural-processed Ethiopia cup.

Name: Geisha Veracruz
Review: A lovely rendition of the admired Geisha variety of Arabica, produced and roasted in Mexico: sweetly tart, balanced, vibrant, engaging.

Name: Ethiopia Duromina
Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia Region, Ethiopia
Review: A friendly, accessible washed Ethiopia with sweet herbal notes supporting the caramel-toned center.

Name: Ethiopia Shakiso Natural
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Southern Ethiopia
Review: A fruit-centered, natural-processed Guji cup with the slightest, very pleasant, hint of sweet ferment, evocative of an oak barrel that’s held a fine wine.

Name: Yemen
Review: A lovely introduction to the pleasures of Yemen: fruit-toned yet balanced, floral yet restrained, and mysterious with its throughline of deep aromatic wood that is more perfumy than earthy.

Name: Heritage Blend
Review: An inviting representation of an all-natural-processed blend: cleanly fruity with elegant undertones of cocoa and aromatic bergamot.

Name: China Yunnan Natural
Review: A clean, confident natural-processed coffee from China’s Yunnan Province, an excellent representation of this expanding coffee-growing region’s potential for quality.

Name: Karimiuki Kenya
Review: A juicy Kenya cup with deep red berry notes, rich chocolate throughout, and deep, spice-toned florals.

Name: Colombia San Pedro
Review: A pretty washed Colombia cup with notes of stone fruit and cocoa nib as deep, satisfying throughlines; particularly vibrant acidity.

Name: DR Congo, Gera Village, SOPACDI
Origin: South Kivu Province, the Democratic Republic of the Congo
Review: An especially juicy, high-toned DR Congo cup with notes of citrus zest and bright stone fruit grounded by earthy-perfumy amber-like suggestions.

Name: Colombia Buesaco
Review: A balanced, engaging, classic Colombia cup: bright, chocolaty, deeply sweet, richly vibrant.

Name: El Floral Colombia
Review: A multi-layered, nuanced Colombia cup that hits all the right notes: deep florals, high-toned fruits, sweet herbs, rich cocoa.

Name: El Salvador Geisha Natural
Review: An elegant, lyrical natural-process El Salvador Geisha cup, sweetly fruit- and floral-toned; a coffee that steps lightly but with poise and balance.

Name: Colombia Pink Bourbon Honey
Review: A deeply sweet, balanced Colombia cup characterized by rich floral and spice tones throughout, with an especially lively acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Guji Lot D Minor
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Southern Ethiopia
Review: A lyrical, delicately balanced, floral-driven natural-processed Ethiopia cup, complete and exhilarating.

Name: Taiwan Natural Alishan Zhuo-Wu Farm Geisha
Review: A rare and exceptional Taiwan-grown Geisha centered around notes of dried berry, deep chocolate and an enticing frankincense.

Name: All Rise
Origin: Ethiopia; Democratic Republic of the Congo
Review: A collaborative coffee by two Virginia roasters whose proceeds benefit the anti-racism work of Dream Corps: bright, sweet, tart, chocolaty and floral — delicious and worthy.

Name: Rwanda Natural Musasa
Review: An elegantly delicate natural-processed Rwanda cup with clean berry notes throughout supported by deep, dark chocolate.

Name: Nano Challa #6 Ethiopia
Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Review: A pleasing washed-process Ethiopia cup with especially engaging acidity and pretty spice-toned floral notes throughout.

Name: El Salvador Pacamara
Review: A complex El Salvador Pacamara cup with cocoa-toned stone fruit and bittersweet florals throughout.

Name: Honduras Finca La Joya Natural
Review: The dried-in-the-fruit, natural processing makes this coffee atypical for Honduras. Here it encourages a range of dried fruit flavors. Sales of this coffee help support a local girls’ orphanage at origin.

Name: Lone Peak Blend
Review: An unusual blend of natural- and anaerobic-processed coffees roasted to medium-dark to develop caramel and floral tones.

Name: Instant Karma
Review: A very appealing instant cup comprised of natural-processed coffees from three origins, supporting a philanthropic effort to provide coffee to essential workers.

Name: 40-Hour Ethiopia Girma Eshetu
Origin: Bita Genet District, Keffa Zone, southwestern Ethiopia
Review: A bargain opportunity for coffee lovers to compare a sample of coffee from the same trees processed using a commercial yeast added to the tank during ferment and a sample fermented in the usual way, influenced only by wild yeasts.

Name: Costa Rica Hacienda Tobosi Copey Villa Sarchi Black Honey
Review: A decadent, dessert-like Costa Rica cup processed by the black honey method, offering especially lively acidity and full, viscous mouthfeel.

Name: Sudan Rume
Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia
Review: An exciting cup from a rare varietal that, in this incarnation, is richly cocoa-toned and spice-laden, complex and multi-layered.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Keramo Village
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A high-toned washed Sidama cup complexly layered with notes of sweet fruit, tart herb, deep cocoa and flowers.

Name: Red Bourbon Natural Exclusive Reserve
Origin: North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii
Review: A natural-processed Kona coffee with an interesting fruit-toned profile and a pleasing throughline of lactic-style acidity (think fresh yogurt); quite compelling as a pourover.

Name: Nano Genji Agaro Gera
Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Review: A deeply fruit-toned washed Ethiopia cup, brought far enough along in the roast to develop big chocolate notes.

Name: Sumatra Pantan Musara
Review: A washed-process Sumatra with engaging high-toned fruit and complex spice tones not typical of the usual wet-hulled coffees produced in this region. Drink it for its originality and its intrigue.

Name: Quadratic Wizard Blend
Review: A deft blend of coffees, both washed and natural-processed, that nets a sweet, rich, chocolate- and fruit-toned cup.

Name: Colombia Nariño
Review: A balanced, chocolaty Colombia cup with especially engaging, high-toned acidity.

Name: Hoyt’s Crossing
Review: A medium-roasted blend that highlights the chocolate and floral notes of coffees from El Salvador and Peru.

Name: Black Dragon Dark Roast
Review: A confident darker roast edging into sweet smokiness, animated by big chocolate notes. Adding a splash of whole milk, or even cream, wouldn’t be a disservice to this strong-charactered dark roast.

Name: Kona Classic Black Rock Farm
Review: A superb example of the classic Kona cup: exceptionally sweet, deeply nut-toned, and vivified by spice-toned floral and fruit notes.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Natural
Review: A cleanly fruit-toned natural-process Ethiopia cup animated by bright berry and deeply sweet floral tones.

Name: Colombia Cauca At’e
Review: A bright, lively Colombia cup with tart fruit, sweet floral, and deep toffee notes throughout — elegantly structured.

Name: Sumatra Pantan Musara
Review: A pretty washed (not wet-hulled) Sumatra, rich and nuanced, with tropical fruit and cocoa notes throughout, all amplified by deep honeysuckle-like florals.

Name: Sumatra Gayo G1 Triple-Picked Lot 005
Review: A classic Sumatra cup: vibrantly earthy, richly sweet and balanced — harmonizing high-toned stone fruit and floral notes with deep chocolate and sweet earth.

Name: Guatemala Guaya’B Coop
Review: A straight-ahead, friendly Guatemala cup, certified organic.

Name: Kakalove Taiwan Natural SL34 Alishan Ching-Ye Farm
Review: A gently berry-toned, natural-processed cup from the growing region of Alishan in Taiwan, a region mainly famous for its tea.

Name: Ignacio Quintero Colombia
Review: A resolutely bright, juicy, deep Colombia cup, transparent in its coherence and thoroughly appealing in its power.

Name: Bella Carmona Guatemala
Review: A balanced, complete cup with an especially attractive, viscous and lively mouthfeel.

Name: Suyusama Colombia
Review: A balanced, lively Colombia cup from a cooperative of 900 smallholding farmers in Nariño, Colombia: richly sweet, chocolaty, and nut-toned.

Name: Ethiopia BergWu SP Series: Wuri Red Cherries 19/EXP02
Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Review: An intentionally fermenty, fruit-centered Ethiopia cup processed by an experimental method involving oxygen deprivation during the fermentation process: sweet, chocolaty, pleasantly funky.

Name: Kenya AB Top
Review: A bold, deep Kenya cup driven by classic black currant notes and rounded by dark chocolate suggestions.

Name: Ka’u Giant Maragogipe
Origin: Ka’u growing region, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: A beautiful expression of the sweet-savory genius of the rare Maragogipe variety: rich, deep, and confident, with notes of wild honey and sweet stone fruit.

Name: Wood Valley Single Estate Ka’u
Origin: Ka’u growing region, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: A higher-altitude Ka’u-grown coffee animated by spicy floral and sweet nut tones.

Name: Kona Maragogype
Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: A rare, small-production Hawaii-grown Maragogype worth going out of your way for: complex, multi-layered, rich and deep.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Agaro-Nano Challa
Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Review: A particularly fruit-driven cup for a washed-process Ethiopia: lively, juicy, resoundingly bright.

Name: Kerinci Palompek Sumatra
Review: Paradoxically sweet and savory, but harmoniously integrated, this vibrant Sumatra cup touches all the right notes: floral- and earth-toned in balance, supported by gentle stone fruit and almond.

Name: Guatemala Vista Al Bosque
Review: A richly sweet Guatemala cup with a throughline of vanilla-like florals and deep, dark chocolate.

Name: Session Blend
Review: A balanced, friendly blend, deftly roasted to bring out chocolate notes, enlivened by a crisp, gentle citrus.

Name: Peaberry Medium Roast
Origin: North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii
Review: A chocolaty and floral-toned Kona Typica peaberry cup, richly layered, softly intriguing.

Name: Lover’s Quarrel
Review: A single-origin coffee from Bali with a darker roast profile, a good choice for those who prefer coffees with lower perceived acidity.

Name: Kenya Embu Gicherori Factory AA Top
Review: A gorgeous rendition of the classic Kenya cup: juicy, sweetly bright, lushly floral- and fruit-toned.

Name: 9 Bar
Review: A complex, nuanced blend with layered depth: richly sweet, floral-toned.

Name: Colombia Huila Los Lagos Washed Geisha
Review: A thoroughly floral Colombia Geisha cup with high-toned notes of jasmine and deep, darker florals akin to tea rose — all enveloped in baking chocolate.

Name: Coffea Diversa Liberica Carbonic Maceration
Review: An exceedingly rare coffee in all respects: A genuinely fine coffee produced from trees of the overlooked and poorly regarded Liberica species, processed by the still unusual carbonic maceration method. The result is a cup that is wildly original and engagingly complex.

Name: Ethiopia Nano Genji #4
Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Review: A pretty washed Ethiopia cup with a distinct floral throughline: think candied violet with undertones of cocoa nib.

Name: Red Bourbon Washed
Origin: North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii
Review: A nuanced, layered Kona cup characterized by stone fruit and sweet floral tones with a savory, cardamom-like depth.

Name: Typica Natural
Origin: Captain Cook, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii
Review: A deftly medium roasted Kona Typica with pleasing chocolate notes and undercurrents of sweet, spearmint-like herbs and spice-toned florals.

Name: Finca Kusillo Bolivia
Review: A balanced, complex, floral-toned cup, particularly pleasing in its nectar-like mouthfeel.

Name: Capital Cold Brew
Origin: Brazil; Colombia; Rwanda; Democratic Republic of the Congo
Review: A roundly refreshing blend designed for homemade cold-brew: caramelly, floral and citrusy.

Name: Colombia Finca Lord Baltimore Papayo
Review: A bright, richly aromatic Colombia cup from a rare tree variety worth seeking out: intricately balanced, exceptionally high-toned, both rich and delicate.

Name: Hawai’i Ka’u Typica Anaerobic Washed
Origin: Ka’u growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Review: Innovative processing helps develop a complex, multi-layered version of the traditional Hawai’i Typica cup: rich, resonant, deeply sweet with savory undertones.

Name: Lekali Estate Reserve Nepal
Review: A solid coffee from Nepal, worth seeking out for its unusual origin and its sweetness and balance.

Name: Gary & Valerie, Kona
Review: A pretty, laid-back Kona Typica cup: floral and fruit-driven, balanced, complete.

Name: Salvador, Kona
Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Review: A throughline of gently smoky aromatic wood anchors perfumy florals and rich dark chocolate.

Name: Mocha Java
Review: A paradoxically richly savory yet singingly sweet interpretation of the classic Mocha Java blend — complex, nuanced, multi-layered.

Name: Ethiopia Shantawene Washed
Origin: idamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia
Review: An exceptional washed-process Sidama cup evoking a garden in spring, vivid with complex sweet-spicy florals. Plus, it’s certified organic.

Name: Organic Suke Quto Ethiopia
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: Juicy, flamboyantly layered honey-processed Ethiopia coffee with notes of tart stone fruit, rich aromatic wood and undertones of fresh-cut spearmint.

Name: Kenya Tuikit Factory AA
Review: An achingly complete Kenya cup that evokes all the pleasures this origin can offer: both deep and high-toned, invitingly sweet and provocatively savory.

Name: Karen J Kona Red Bourbon
Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii
Review: We taste this coffee year-in and year-out, and it never fails to satisfy. This may be Kona’s version of a reliable non-vintage Champagne: consistently delicious.

Name: Abu Natural Panama Geisha
Review: A dessert-like natural-processed Panama Geisha cup, all fruit and flowers and chocolate, heady in its aromatic and flavor intensity.

Name: Sumatra Lintong Triple-Picked Reserve
Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia
Review:
A classic Sumatra: sweetly pungent fruit, fresh earth and dry, chocolaty
grace notes.

Name: Colombia Finca Las Margaritas Natural Sudan Rume
Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia
Review: Intensely sweet, boldly fermenty, soothingly seductive with its winy aromas and flavors.

Name: Ecuador Finca Carolina Sidra
Review: An impressive rendition of the rare variety Sidra, recently genetically confirmed as a hybrid of Ethiopian indigenous landrace varieties. It offers here an intoxicating range of sweet, floral, citrus, and spice tones.

Name: Ethiopia Konga
Review: A sweetly dry medium-roasted washed Ethiopia cup with a juicy, peach-toned heart.

Name: Gesha Village Single-Variety Gesha Special Selection
Review: A pretty natural-processed Ethiopia Gesha produced at the highly regarded Gesha Village estate, with deep floral and fruit tones in harmonious balance.

Name: DR Congo Muungano
Origin: South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Review: A complexly structured DR Congo cup with high-pitched acidity at one end and deep-dive tobacco notes at the other, nuanced by a throughline of vanilla-like florals.

Name: Colombian
Review: A classic Colombia cup: big-bodied, roundly bright, straight-ahead.

Name: Magnolia Blend
Review: A friendly coffee — balanced, comforting, deeply chocolate-toned with cherryish fruit and a hint of sultry gardenia.

Name: Rwanda Gatare Namasheke
Review: A sweet, floral Rwanda cup with pleasing, complex notes of dried stone fruit and cocoa.

Name: Indestec El Paraiso
Review: A washed-process Colombia driven by notes of tropical fruit, with an especially exhilarating acidity.

Name: Monteblanco Cold Fermentation Geisha
Review: A bright, exciting Colombia Geisha with concentrated stone fruit and both sweet and savory floral notes in aroma and throughout the profile.

Name: Funky Chicken
Review: A deep, richly sweet blend, deftly roasted to medium-dark, with cocoa for miles and stone fruit and florals throughout — an impressive bargain at $13.99/12 ounces ($79.00/5 pounds).

Name: Dirty South
Review: A pleasing Colombia blend that the roaster says is “as dark as we will go” — in this case a discreetly achieved dark end of medium.

Name: Ten Anniversary Blend
Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Review: A fruit bomb kept in check by a savory throughline: deep sweetness juxtaposed with umami gravitas.

Name: 4&20 French Roast
Review: A chocolaty fair-trade/organic blend with spice-toned florals animating a balanced, resonantly medium-dark roasted cup.

Name: Seasonal Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural
Review: A fruit-forward natural-process Ethiopia cup with lush sweet ferment throughout.

Name: Floyd Farmhouse Blend
Review: A friendly, accessible “breakfast blend”: cocoa-driven, enlivened by crisp berry notes.

Name: Yemen Al-Obbarat
Review: A lush, juicy expression of the classic Yemen profile: cleanly fruit-toned, a bit spicy, richly sweet, strikingly and subtly nuanced.

Name: Ecuador Quilanga Typica Yeast Fermentation
Review: An unusual and evocative cup, paradoxically sweet and savory, with layered complexity.

Name: S.O. Espresso Brazil Fazenda Cachoeira Yellow Bourbon
Review: Designed as a single-origin espresso but cupped here for brewed applications, this natural-processed Brazil coffee offers a gentle, sweetly nut-toned cup.

Name: Rwanda Hingakawa Women’s Co-op
Review: Cocoa nib and warm spice notes characterize this enveloping, richly sweet Rwanda cup produced by a women’s cooperative.

Name: DR Congo Muungano Co-op South Kivu
Origin: South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Review: A compelling, deep-toned DR Congo cup with resonantly spicy floral notes throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Guji PB JackyLai Lot
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A berry- and cocoa-toned cup with especially lively acidity. A dried-in-the-fruit or natural-processed coffee without a whisper of ferment, all sweet fruit and rich aromatic wood notes.

Name: Rwanda Kiroero
Review: An engaging, balanced Rwanda cup: deeply sweet with rich, buttery nut tones throughout.

Name: Kakalove Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Boyrfi
Review: A fruit-bomb of a natural-process Yirgacheffe, with unmistakable blueberry notes throughout.

Name: Rus & Alla Ka’u
Review: A classic Ka’u cup: balanced, both bright and deep, richly nut-toned.

Name: Colombia Geisha
Review: A pleasing introduction to the Geisha variety in an affordable Colombian rendition: classically sweet, richly aromatic.

Name: La Naranja Honduras
Review: A richly sweet, almost dessert-like Honduras coffee, fermented experimentally with orange peel.

Name: Mexico FTO
Origin: Motozintla de Mendoza, Chiapas State, Mexico
Review: An engagingly cocoa-toned Mexico cup with solid sustainable credentials.

Name: Ethiopia Wush Wush
Review: A rare indigenous Ethiopia variety and a long, oxygen-suppressed fermentation results in an extraordinary cup: soaring, exotic, unique.

Name: Ethiopia Hassen Ware Akrabi
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A complex, floral-toned cup with a stone fruit throughline and nut brittle undertones.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Bombe Natural
Review: A superb choice for those who like fruit-driven coffees without fermenty alcohol notes — berry tones are front and center.

Name: Ethiopia Adame Garbota
Review: A richly bracing cup with citrus and floral aromatics reminiscent of Earl Grey tea, but powerfully expressed in coffee terms.

Name: Rwanda Bumbogo
Review: A fine Rwanda cup with deep sweetness animated by delicate fruit, floral and cocoa notes.

Name: Ethiopia Danse Mormora
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia
Review: An engaging washed-process Ethiopia cup with a particularly vibrant mouthfeel and satisfying, balanced structure.

Name: Ethiopia Keramo Washed
Review: An accessible and engagingly classic washed-process Ethiopia: crisp, balanced and very sweet.

Name: Congo Boza
Review: A richly sweet, earth-toned Congo coffee with sales benefitting a women-owned cooperative.

Name: Kenya Muiri Estate
Review: A rare organic-certified Kenya with a classic Kenya profile: sweet and savory in harmony with balanced acidity.

Name: Costa Rica Luis Campos Anaerobic
Review: Enjoying this Costa Rica evokes the pleasures of walking into a bakery in winter alive with aromas of warming spices and rich cocoa.

Name: Colombia Granja La Esperanza Tres Dragones
Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia
Review: A bombshell of a coffee with enough personality to stand up to a lemon tart — for breakfast, of course.

Name: Kenya Wanjengi AA
Review: A developed medium roast emphasizes this Kenya’s depth and amplifies its rich dried fruit and cocoa notes.

Name: Colombia Finca La Loma Microlot
Review: An exceptional Colombia cup with sweet and tart impulses in balance: deeply sweet florals and bright fruit notes throughout.

Name: Dukunde Kawa Rwanda
Review: A deep yet delicate cup redolent with crisp fruit and spice-toned floral notes.

Name: Buzira Burundi Natural
Review: An exceptionally cleanly expressed natural-processed Burundi cup, citrus- and chocolate-toned.

Name: Ka’u Yellow Caturra Champagne Natural
Origin: Ka’u growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Review: A complex, nuanced Ka’u coffee processed with a strain of wine yeast, encouraging a particularly vibrant, fruit-toned acidity.

Name: Burundi Kibingo
Review: A rich, deeply sweet Burundi cup that evokes gingerbread or similar spice-toned pastries.

Name: Colombia San Pascual Natural
Review: A sweetly fermenty and chocolaty Colombia cup that invokes a rum-cordial-like combination of intense chocolate and fruity liqueur.

Name: Kenya Kiambu AB Uklili 1905 Lot
Review: A classic Kenya cup: bright and juicy with leading notes of dark berry and sweet florals; especially high-toned, lively acidity.

Name: Birambo Village DR Congo
Origin: South Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Review: A balanced, sweetly savory DR Congo cup with dried fruit and chocolate notes throughout.

Name: KonAroma Direct Trade Kona
Origin: Kona growing district, Big Island of Hawaii
Review: A pretty, richly sweet Kona cup that leads with deep floral and nut tones.

Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu Hacienda La Pradera
Review: A balanced washed process Costa Rica cup, lively, accessible, engaging.

Name: Elida Natural Dragonfly Lot
Review: A decidedly fruit-centered coffee with pleasing sweet ferment and rich chocolate notes throughout.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Yirgacheffe FTO
Review: A classic washed process Yirgacheffe cup: juicy and bright with citrus and stonefruit notes throughout and a cocoa throughline.

Name: Guatemala Maravillas
Review: A sturdy, bittersweet cup, roundly raisiny and nut-toned.

Name: Kona Laurina Pointu
Review: An unusual and compelling coffee: brisk but very sweet, with peach and deep, musky florals.

Name: Kona K7
Review: A pleasingly balanced cup, quiet, accessible and subtly original.

Name: Kona SL34
Review: A fresh, sweet-toned cup: morning in a meadow.

Name: Ethiopia Dimtu
Origin: Hambela Wamena District, Guji Zone, Ethiopia
Review: A lyrical washed-process Ethiopia cup: intricately balanced, complex, juicy, confident.

Name: Kona Double-Washed Black Rock Farm
Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Review: A solid Kona cup that leads with nut tones and bright, yet accessible, acidity.

Name: Peru Aproselva
Review: A roast-toned, sweetly chocolaty Peru cup with dried fruit and floral notes throughout.

Name: Tanzania AA Karatu Estate
Review: An impeccably balanced, nuanced Tanzania cup that is an extraordinary value at $12 for 12 ounces.

Name: Ethiopia Yetagesu Bulebula
Review: A classic washed Yirgacheffe cup: bright, lively, redolent of stone fruit, citrus zest and cocoa.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Darii Kojowa Grade 1
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia
Review: An inviting, rich-toned natural-processed Ethiopia cup with clear blueberry and chocolate notes and gentle acidity.

Name: Kenya Kevota Makengi
Review: A robust, hearty Kenya, driven by sweet-pungent grapefruit and cedar, softened by dark chocolate suggestions.

Name: Ethiopia Reko Estate Yirgacheffe
Review: Sweet flowers and intense sandalwood power this silky-bodied, fragrant Yirgacheffe.

Name: H Coffee Blend D02
Review: A bright, balanced blend driven by stone fruit and citrus with a floral throughline.

Name: H Coffee Blend F03
Review: An accessible blend: sweet and nutty with pleasant cocoa tones throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Anaerobic
Review: A quietly original, resonant cup, exquisitely balanced and complete.

Name: Kenya Kiri Peaberry
Review: A deeply rich, big-bodied Kenya cup foregrounding spice notes, berries and bittersweet florals.

Name: Kenya Nyeri AA Ichuga
Review: A solid Kenya cup: chocolaty, spice-toned, deeply sweet.

Name: Hacienda La Esmeralda Geisha Panama
Review: An accessible Geisha cup characterized by tropical fruit and cocoa notes throughout with intimations of honey-like florals.

Name: San Sebastian Colombia
Review: A big-bodied Colombia driven by crisp chocolate and nut intrigue rounded by cherryish fruit.

Name: La Coipa Peru
Review: A richly expressed, crisply bittersweet microlot from a tiny, woman-owned and operated farm in Peru.

Name: Ethiopia Violent Andromeda Natural
Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Review: A fruit- and chocolate- bomb of a coffee, dessert-like with its rich-toned, candy-like sweetness.

Name: Idido
Review: A classic Ethiopia profile: cocoa- and citrus-toned. Given the distinction of the coffee, an outstanding value.

Name: Ethiopia FTO
Review: A friendly, straightforward washed Ethiopia cup with both organic and fair trade credentials.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A washed Sidamo cup with a developed roast profile that  amplifies chocolate and floral notes; deeply and richly sweet throughout.

Name: Colombia
Review: A deftly medium-roasted Colombia cup, balanced and satisfying in its familiar pleasures.

Name: Kenya Zuri
Review: A straightforward, accessible Kenya cup with big chocolate notes as a throughline.

Name: Guatemala Dark Roast FTO
Review: A darker-roasted Guatemala coffee that highlights pleasing cocoa and dried fruit notes.

Name: Honduras Atanacio Nolasco
Review: A pleasing, balanced Honduras cup with pretty nut tones throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia
Review: An easy-drinking natural-processed Ethiopia cup with ballast from spice-toned aromatic wood and florals.

Name: Sidamo Suke Quto
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A medium-roasted Ethiopia cup with pleasing cocoa and citrus notes throughout; wood-centered in the finish.

Name: Guatemala (from bulk bin)
Review: A good-value darker roasted Guatemala driven by quiet chocolate and nut notes.

Name: Colombia
Review: A comfortingly familiar, darker roasted Colombia cup built around dark chocolate with undertones of vanilla-like florals.

Name: Colombia
Review: A roast-prominent, cocoa-toned Colombia cup with an intriguing sweet-tart note.

Name: 100% Guatemalan
Review: A sweet though muted Guatemala cup: roasty cocoa and nut.

Name: Sumatra Dark
Review: A good choice for those who like classic dark-roasted Sumatras: earthy-sweet, smoky chocolate.

Name: 100% Kona Bourbon Pointu Laurina
Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii
Review: An aromatically complex, original cup that balances an enveloping sweetness with a quietly forceful pungency.

Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Geisha Natural Special Auction ES-N-2
Review: An elegant, subtle coffee with leading notes of stonefruit and cocoa nib and especially lively acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Uraga Wolisho Natural
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A balanced, straightforward natural-process Ethiopia cup: sweetly tart, chocolaty, with a hint of spicy florals throughout.

Name: Lian House Blend
Origin: Peru; Colombia; Guatemala; Ecuador; Ethiopia; Brazil
Review: An accessible, sweet-toned blend with gentle fruit and floral notes and nut and aromatic wood undertones.

Name: Guatemala Maragogype La Providencia
Review: A striking cup from this rare variety: sweet, tart, rich, deep, and floral through and through.

Name: El Salvador Finca El Cerro Natural
Review: A resonantly fruit-forward, cocoa-toned natural-processed Pacamara cup, with high-toned florals and richly bittersweet citrus notes throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Shakiso
Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia
Review: An elegant, richly-layered single-farm Ethiopia cup. Natural processing develops sweet berry notes throughout.

Name: Madagascar Yellow Bourbon Santatra Coop
Review: An intriguing cup from the little-known coffee-producing region Madagascar: sweet, tart, balanced and inviting.

Name: Finca La Montana Costa Rica
Review: A richly sweet and fruit-forward Costa Rica cup with a developed roast profile that highlights chocolate and floral tones.

Name: Berg Wu Championship Selection Yirgacheffe G1 Natural Lot 19/01
Review: A lively, engaging, cleanly fruit-toned natural-processed Yirgacheffe cup deepened by low-toned florals akin to fine musk.

Name: Ethiopia Mulegeta Sintayehu Washed
Review: A complex, resonant washed Ethiopia cup, fruit- and flora-laden, with an especially inviting bright, juicy acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Bensa Asefa Dukamo Washed
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: An engaging, complex yet accessible washed Ethiopia cup characterized by crisp fruit and deep floral tones.

Name: Ecuador Eugenioides Natural Finca Perla Negra
Review: Both surprising in aromatics and richly reassuring in sweetness and balance. Look for this very rare coffee when it comes around again in 2020 at Paradise Roasters.

Name: Panama Esmeralda Geisha Natural
Review: A high-toned, richly floral natural-processed Geisha cup from the famed Hacienda La Esmeralda farm in Boquete, Panama animated by crisp, citrusy fruit notes throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Suke Quto Honey
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A deeply nuanced coffee with bittersweet citrus and sweet florals in front and ballast from rich chocolate and nougat.

Name: Kenya FSC AB
Review: A big, chocolaty Kenya cup with deep floral notes throughout and a particularly engaging, syrupy-smooth body.

Name: Colombia Pink Bourbon
Review: A rich-toned Colombia cup characterized by tart red fruit and citrus notes supported by deep florals and a crisp sweetness akin to maple syrup.

Name: Guatemala Acatenango Geisha
Review: An accessible Guatemala Geisha with floral top notes and stone fruit and cocoa tones in the cup.

Name: Kenya Kiambu “Summer Love”
Review: A friendly, accessible medium-roasted Kenya cup with sweet fruit and floral notes throughout.

Name: El Salvador Pacamara Honey
Review: An aromatic-wood-framed, honey-processed Pacamara from El Salvador with depth from cocoa and spice tones.

Name: Ceri Ceri Meriah Coffee
Review: A high-toned coffee from West Java with a particularly bright structure, syrupy mouthfeel and emphasis on attractive stone fruit and sweet floral notes.

Name: Alamendah Patuha Coffee
Review: A rich and nuanced savory-sweet Indonesia cup, honey-processed and fruit-forward, with ballast from citrus and aromatic wood notes.

Name: Puna Champagne Natural Anaerobic
Review: A fruit- and floral-toned coffee from a lesser-known growing region on the Big Island of Hawai’i is worth seeking out for its balanced completeness and its suggestions of the tropics, both aromatically and in the cup.

Name: Costa Rica Las Lajas Red Honey
Review: A sweet, multi-layered Costa Rica cup, its rich fruit amplified by skillful red honey processing.

Name: Refisa Ethiopia
Review: A classically bright, floral-toned washed Ethiopia cup with added vivacity from stone fruit and citrus notes.

Name: La Lindura Colombia
Review: A balanced Colombia cup with notes of stonefruit and citrus on top and deep cocoa and rich aromatic wood underneath.

Name: Butare Huye of Rwanda
Review: A Rwanda cup pleasingly balanced between sweet fruit and chocolate and rich aromatic wood.

Name: La Finca Medina of Guatemala
Review: Enjoy this straightforward Central America cup for its mild acidity and its sweet nut and deep floral notes.

Name: Peaberry Blend
Review: An attractive choice for lovers of darker-roasted blends: sweet chocolate and flowers alongside dried fruit notes, with prominent smoky wood throughout.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: A bright, balanced blend of natural- and washed-process Ethiopia coffees, each contributing to the cup’s impressive depth and range of sensory pleasures.

Name: 2019 Celebration
Review: A roast-forward blend that emphasizes chocolate and floral notes while developing the savory inclination of the green coffees as well: rich, musky, sweet. Might be particularly nice — apologies to purists — with a splash of milk.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: A complex, layered coffee with both classic Kenya (red currant) and Ethiopia (berry, cocoa) leanings.

Name: Holiday Sweet Blend
Review: An integrated, harmonious blend of washed- and natural-process coffees that highlights both sweet (blueberry) and tart (tamarind) fruits with big chocolate throughout.

Name: Winter Solstice Blend
Review: A sweetly nutty and cocoa-toned cup with an especially buoyant mouthfeel.

Name: Festivity Blend
Review: An engaging, delicately spice-inflected blend pleasingly complicated by chocolate and citrus zest.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: A subtle, nuanced cup rich with notes of spicy florals and baking spices with an appealing berry throughline.

Name: Invincible Sun God
Review: This coffee’s name is loosely drawn from the name of the winter solstice celebration for Mithraism, "Natalis Solis Invincti," which means “birthday of the unconquerable sun.” Drink it if for no other reason than this.

Name: Wonderland Winter Solstice Holiday Blend
Review: A friendly, balanced blend, equally sweet and tart, animated by a delicate cocoa.

Name: Dark Roast Holiday Blend
Review: An interesting blend skillfully dark-roasted, save for the bitter, burned finish. Otherwise, quietly intriguing, sweet and smoky.

Name: Kenya Kiandu Peaberry
Review: A beautifully balanced, classically sweet-savory Kenya cup with great depth and sweet, musky resonance.

Name: Ethiopia Idido Wegida
Review: A deeply sweet washed-process Ethiopia cup, spice-toned with elegant suggestions of dried stone fruit.

Name: Kenya Kirinyaga
Review: A balanced, sweet-savory Kenya cup with classic currant notes and a rich bittersweet undercurrent suggesting hop flowers throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Herfusa Single Variety Natural
Review: A cleanly fruit-driven natural-processed Yirgacheffe cup, berry- and nut-toned with sweet florals throughout.

Name: Mbeguka Kenya
Review: A deeply sweet Kenya with classic red berry notes, bittersweet florals, and minty herb notes.

Name: Guatemala La Folie
Review: A friendly, accessible Guatemala cup that leads with pleasing nut tones supported by spice-toned fruit. Gentle though expressive acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Washed
Review: A delicate, accessible, pretty Ethiopia cup with attractive citrus and chocolate notes.

Name: Costa Rica Farmer’s Project
Review: An appealing blend of Costa Rica coffees that supports a local farmer’s collective: crisp, sweet and balanced.

Name: Guatemala Concepción Buena Vista
Review: A friendly, accessible Central America cup, crisply sweet with notes of stone fruit, cocoa and hazelnut.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Aricha G1
Review: A classic washed Yirgacheffe cup: bright and lively with juicy, vibrant acidity.

Name: El Salvador Las Mercedes Pacamara Honey
Review: A deeply sweet Pacamara cup with savory undertones throughout, reminiscent of fine musk and marjoram-like sweet herbs.

Name: Panama Esmeralda Geisha Portón Oro Yeast
Review: An exceptionally high-toned natural-processed Panama Geisha coffee with especially vibrant acidity, balanced structure, and deep floral notes throughout the profile.

Name: Kenya Kiambu Peaberry Uklili 1904 Lot
Review: A crisp, sweet-toned, cocoa-laden Kenya cup elevated by citrusy floral notes.

Name: Kenya Kiambu AB Uklili 1903 Lot
Review: A chocolaty and floral-toned Kenya cup with ballast from zesty citrus and rich aromatic wood.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Blue Donkey Lot #2
Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: An exceptionally purely expressed natural-processed Yirgacheffe cup, berry- and nut-driven, supported by spicy floral notes throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Nansebo Worka
Review: An elegant, high-toned, washed-process Yirgacheffe cup saturated with floral and fruit notes throughout and a particularly engaging sweet-citrusy acidity.

Name: Panama Elida Geisha Natural 1029
Review: An ethereal Panama Geisha cup, intricately balanced, infinitely deep, lyrically sweet.

Name: Port of Mokha Yemen JSP
Origin: Al Hayma growing region, Al Kharijiyah District, Sana’a Governorate, Yemen
Review: An immense, engaging coffee: classically Yemen with cocoa, fruit and tobacco and a deep, quiet elegance.

Name: Panama Elida Natural Catuai
Review: An explosively sweet, fruit-forward natural-processed coffee produced by the same farm that gave us the latest price-record-breaking, most sought-after Geisha in the world. Consider this coffee a worthy and affordable cousin.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe GR1 Bedhatu Jibicho Washed
Review: A balanced, crisply herb-toned washed Yirgacheffe cup deepened by sweet stonefruit notes.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Othaya Gura AA
Review: A balanced, cocoa-driven Kenya cup with classic currant notes and rich florals throughout.

Name: Signature Blend
Review: A straightforward, accessible blend that mirrors the fast-casual restaurant setting in which it’s served.

Name: Ethiopia Konga Natural
Review: A rich-toned Yirgacheffe whose processing method (natural) highlights the cup’s fruit-forward qualities.

Name: Kenya Ndaroini
Review: A medium-roasted Kenya that highlights the coffee’s chocolate tendencies, with lively, high-toned acidity.

Name: Harimau Tiger Sumatra
Origin: Mandheling growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia
Review: An alluring Sumatra cup, both classic and innovative: sweetly earth-framed (classic) but profoundly high-toned (innovative) with nuanced complexity.

Name: Gachami Kenya
Review: A classic Kenya cup with bright, juicy fruit and lively sweet-tart acidity.

Name: Finca Santa Isabel Guatemala
Review: A straightforward, deeply sweet, cocoa-laden Guatemala cup.

Name: Washed Geisha Hacienda La Esmeralda Jaramillo Special
Review: A stunning, high-toned Geisha, downright majestic in the clarity of its aromatics and lyrical structure.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela Natural
Review: A friendly, accessible Ethiopia cup animated by pleasing berry and spicy floral notes.

Name: Panama Perci Geisha Natural
Review: A lush, juicy, tropical natural-processed profile overlaid on a deep, spicy/savory profile with something else as well, an edge we might associate with fermented foods like yogurt or pickles. Clearly for coffee adventurers.

Name: Cordillera del Fuego Costa Rica Anaerobic
Review: A high-toned, cleanly fruit-forward Costa Rica cup with deeply rich savory underpinnings.

Name: Cordillera del Fuego Costa Rica Anaerobic
Review: An anaerobic-processed coffee whose startling originality leans toward musk, chocolate and cinnamon.

Name: Ethiopia Anaerobic
Review: Drink it for its original yet subtly expressed embodiment of the peculiarly intriguingly sweet-tart genius of anaerobic or lactic acid fermentation.

Name: Costa Rica Anaerobic
Review: The complex, sweet-spicy character of Mexican chocolate dominates in this shifting, surprising, but ultimately balanced cup.

Name: Colombia Finca El Paraiso Double Anaerobic Geisha
Review: The startling aromatic surprises of the Geisha variety are overlaid and intensified by the less familiar surprises of an experimental lactic-acid-inducing fermentation step. For those who pursue the rare and remarkable in beverages.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Adorsi
Review: Drink it for its originality and paradox: Sweet, musky and perfumy yet crisp and bracingly brisk.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Naia Bombe Dry Ferment Vertical Reserve
Review: A processing variation (fermentation without added water) perhaps contributes to the deep, savory-sweet floral-toned intrigue of this fine washed-process Ethiopia.

Name: Colombia Monteblanco Gesha Cold Fermentation
Review: Deeply sweet in structure with savory undertones and intriguing, original aromatics centered on brisk, bittersweet flowers.

Name: Costa Rica Brunca Finca Vista Passion Honey
Review: A sweet but brisk cup saturated by a seductive sweet chocolate and a lively lime-like citrus.

Name: Chania Kenya
Review: Drink it if you like a nuanced but bright, sweet-tart cup in the traditional style.

Name: Kenya Kibirigwi Thunguri
Review: A big, juicy, and crisply sweet Kenya cup, with compelling savory undertones and a cocoa throughline.

Name: Elida Estate Geisha Green-Tip Natural
Review: A flawlessly structured coffee alive with layered intrigue, memorable both for its complexity as well as its quiet, enveloping completeness.

Name: Washed Kenya
Review: A powerful and engaging cup, paradoxical in its combination of roasty-savory depth and tart, floral-toned intensity.

Name: Coffea Diversa Bourbon Rey Jamaica
Review: A multi-layered Jamaica coffee with distinct chocolate and spicy floral tones and a throughline of dried fruit reminiscent of fig.

Name: Coffea Diversa Bourbon Rey Guatemala
Review: An elegant, inviting Guatemala cup with a particularly impressive structure, balanced yet buoyant and lively.

Name: Colombia Huila
Review: An intensely bright coffee with attractive, savory-leaning undertones.

Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Super Mario Geisha
Review: A levitatingly sweet and juicy coffee, an extravaganza of fruit and flowers with deep chocolate throughout — pure, yet lavish.

Name: Tablon La Cima
Review: A friendly, accessible cocoa- and nut-toned El Salvador cup.

Name: Nicaragua Finca Idealista
Review: A high-toned Nicaragua cup showing a range of stone fruit, cocoa, and sweet nut in harmonious balance.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Gerbicho Natural
Review: A fruit-forward natural processed Ethiopia cup with ballast from rich cocoa and floral suggestions throughout the profile.

Name: Guatemala San Cristobal
Origin: San Cristobal, Cobán, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala
Review: A crisp, sweetly herbaceous and citrusy Guatemala cup with warming spice tones throughout.

Name: Peru Paltachayoc
Origin: Cusco Department, La Convención Province, Santa Teresa District, Peru
Review: A gently roasty cup redolent of chocolate and deep, spice-toned florals.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Naia Bomb Natural Vertical Reserve
Review: A natural-processed Ethiopia ideal for those who enjoy a restrained hint of fruit ferment, in this case suggesting a just-emptied wine barrel in a cool cellar.

Name: Hernan Zuniga Ecuador
Review: A very sweet Ecuador cup with deep spice tones and a cocoa throughline; especially lively acidity.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Uraga
Review: A washed-process Ethiopia cup with leading notes of stone fruit and spicy florals and an especially inviting texture.

Name: Kenya Gakundu FCS Kamviu Wet Mill
Review: A savory-leaning yet deeply sweet Kenya coffee with the distinct red and black currant notes characteristic of the origin, bittersweet florals and a lively citrus.

Name: Rukira Kenya
Review: A classic Kenya cup: juicy, bright and deeply sweet with an intriguing floral-umani complexity.

Name: Nayo Ovalle Guatemala
Review: A balanced, sweetly nut-driven cup with pretty notes of baker’s chocolate and hints of oak forest that linger into the finish.

Name: Gesha Village Lot #85 Natural
Review: An exquisitely clean natural-processed Gesha cup from Ethiopia, elegantly structured and confidently aromatic.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Banko Gotiti
Origin: Kochere Woreda, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: An enticing natural-processed Ethiopia with big fruit notes supported by deep chocolate, rich aromatic wood and impressive spice-toned florals.

Name: Guatemala Washed Finca El General Pache
Review: A friendly, accessible Guatemala cup: crispy sweet with nut and chocolate throughlines.

Name: Colombia La Esperanza Natural XO
Review: A clean natural-processed Colombia cup from an unusual variety of Arabica — fruit-driven and chocolaty.

Name: Ethiopia Limu Nano Challa Lot #10
Review: A classic washed Ethiopia cup: high-toned, rich and juicy, with notes of stone fruit and flowers throughout.

Name: Best of Panama GNEP-01 Elida Geisha Green Tip Natural
Review: Elegant, lyrical and enchanting, with an integrated presentation of floral, fruit, spice, nut and cocoa tones and an exceptionally balanced and vibrant structure and acidity.

Name: Geisha XO
Review: A cleanly and thoroughly berry-toned natural-processed Geisha with big chocolate notes throughout and satisfying savory underpinnings.

Name: Colombia Finca La Maria Geisha Natural
Review: An unabashedly fruit-centered natural-processed Geisha with big florals to match the fruit and compelling, subtle spice undertones.

Name: Panama Finca Kalithea Natural Geisha
Review: An exquisitely balanced natural-processed Geisha with the deep, sweet complexity the type can offer without a hint of ferment: crisply sweet fruit top and bottom notes, along with rich florals and chocolate tones in the mid-palate, all enhanced by a whisper of sandalwood.

Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Super Mario 6 Geisha
Review: Extravagant florals and spice-toned cocoa notes characterize this deeply sweet, washed-processed Panama cup with a nuanced yet omnipresent umami impulse.

Name: Panama Geisha Alto Jaramillo
Origin: Alto Jaramillo, Boquete growing region, western Panama
Review: An impressively smooth, coherent structure supports a quietly pleasing set of Geisha aromatics. Should satisfy those who may find the full-on Panama Geisha fireworks a bit much but who still enjoy the distinctive character of this rare variety.

Name: Colombia Laderas del Tapias Estate Natural Geisha
Review: A deep berry-toned cup with a juicy hint of sweet ferment and rich cocoa notes throughout.

Name: Gesha Village Natural Lot #19
Review: A beautifully structured natural-processed Ethiopia Gesha, with striking sweetness pleasingly complicated by notes of aromatic resin and tropical fruit.

Name: Gesha Village 1931 Lot 27
Review: A pleasingly coherent coffee that is both sweet and savory in harmonious balance, with floral and fruit tones throughout and an herbaceous note that grounds and enriches the whole.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Girma Natural
Review: A high-toned natural-processed Ethiopia that is fruit-forward without a hint of ferment.

Name: Ethiopia Limu Lema Edeto
Review: A chocolate- and fruit-toned natural-processed Ethiopia coffee with a hint of appealing sweet ferment throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Gora Kone
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A delicately complex and nuanced coffee, subtly composed around fruit and musky floral tones.

Name: Kebele Village Ethiopia
Review: A coffee for those who like their washed Ethiopias high-toned and tart-leaning, with an abiding cocoa- and floral-toned sweetness throughout.

Name: Panama Finca San Sebastian
Review: A resonant expression of the traditional Panama washed cup, driven by deep chocolate notes supported by subtle but persistent sweet floral tones. A bargain at $12 for 12 ounces.

Name: Rwanda Nyarusiza Station
Review: A sweet, pleasingly floral coffee animated by berry and cocoa notes throughout.

Name: Murang’a Kenya
Review: A big-bodied Kenya, zesty, deep, yet delicately layered in the aromatics.

Name: Coffea Diversa Cioiccie
Review: An extremely rare, limited-production coffee procured by Miguel Meza of Paradise Roasters, unique in both backstory and cup.

Name: Yirgacheffe Gedeb G1 Natural
Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Review: A complex, umami- and citrus-driven natural-processed Ethiopia cup that hits all the pleasure spots: sweet, tart and savory in harmonious balance.

Name: Trilogy
Review: A blend of washed and wet-hulled coffees that reads like a friendly Sumatra: sweetly wood-framed with notes of chocolate and baking spices.

Name: Kenya Kiambu Uklili AA
Review: A harmonious, lyrical, balanced Kenya coffee, classic in its expression of both sweet and savory impulses.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Shakisso Natural Lot 24
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Review: An elegant natural-processed Ethiopia that is fruit-forward without a hint of ferment: crisp, clean, juicy-sweet.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe Nafasha Lot
Review: An integrated, citrus-inflected washed Ethiopia cup with a cocoa throughline and spicy floral notes, particularly in the aroma.

Name: La Avila SL28 El Salvador
Origin: Tecapa Chinameca growing region, Santiago de María, southeastern El Salvador
Review: The nut notes are pleasant but just a front; drink it for its grown-up dry chocolate, zesty lime and elderflower notes that emerge with just a little patience.

Name: El Salvador
Origin: Tecapa Chinameca growing region, southeastern El Salvador
Review: Balanced and comprehensive in structure, with a subtle but grand array of aromatics: honey-like flowers, crisp lavender-like flowers, juicy yet savory fruit (we called it roasted pineapple), nut, dry chocolate.

Name: Talquezalar El Salvador
Origin: La Palma, Chalatenango Department, northwestern El Salvador
Review: Both delicate and resonant, animated by sweet, honeyish nut and lime-toned citrus.

Name: Finca Kilimanjaro Natural
Origin: Santa Ana Department, northwestern El Salvador
Review: A nut-toned bitter-savory inclination is lifted majestically by a deep, cherry-like sweetness. Drink it for the contrast, and the big, syrupy mouthfeel.

Name: Finca San Antonio El Salvador
Review: A quietly original Geisha: sweet-savory, complexly aromatic.

Name: Mario Aguilar Grand Cru El Salvador
Review: Cedary dark chocolate and subtle walnut and peach notes make this a particularly accessible version of the great Pacamara profile.

Name: José Flores El Salvador Natural
Review: Almost two coffees, one dominated by a bracing bitter-leaning structure, the other sweet and complexly aromatic. Enjoy it for its paradox and its particularly syrupy mouthfeel.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Worka Gotiti Natural
Review: A sweetly fermenty natural-processed Ethiopia turned slightly more austere by bittersweet floral and spicy aromatic wood notes.

Name: Cold-Drip Blend “Dionysus”
Review: A fruit bomb of a coffee with an abundance of smoky wood and savory tones suggesting pickled vegetables — odd perhaps, but a nice ballast for the big fruit.

Name: Ethiopia Kayon Mountain Natural
Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia
Review: Lovely Ethiopia natural: cleanly fruit-toned, crisp, resonant, and sweet through and through.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Blue Donkey Lot
Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A juicy, rich natural-processed Yirgacheffe cup with clean fruit and cocoa tones throughout and an appealing savory edge.

Name: Kenya Chania Estate
Review: A pleasing umami-driven Kenya that foreground notes of sweet, ripe tomato with enveloped in rich florals and crisp chocolate.

Name: Guatemala Los Santos
Review: A richly bittersweet Guatemala cup punctuated by pretty notes of citrus zest throughout.

Name: Geisha Village Auction Lot #11
Review: Exhilarating, bright, balmy: like drinking a spring day with a cocoa chaser.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Chelelektu Natural
Review: A complex, nuanced expression of a natural-processed Yirgacheffe coffee: fruit-forward, balanced, juicy and multi-layered — the fruit-centered genius of a natural conveyed with the completeness and inevitability of a classic.

Name: Kenya Kimaruri
Review: A classic Kenya cup: sweet, tart, juicy all wrapped together with deep-toned red fruit and spicy floral notes.

Name: Zambia Kateshi Natural
Review: A pretty, fruit-prominent natural-processed coffee expressing balance and finesse.

Name: Kenya Handege
Review: Rather than the typical Kenya black currant and cocoa profile, this equally remarkable Kenya is driven by the intensity of the musky/rich elements and the juicy stone fruit and citrus.

Name: Kauai Estate Reserve Sun-Dried Typica
Review: Quiet, round, crisply balanced, with sweet stone fruit and cocoa supported by savory-leaning nut and oak.

Name: Colombia Valle del Cauca Cerro Azul Geisha
Origin: Valle del Cauca Department, western Colombia
Review: Grandly intense yet sweetly agreeable: seethes with complex floral and brightly juicy fruit notes.

Name: Ecuador Loja Clara Sidra Natural Taza Dorada #2
Review: A sweetly bright yet roundly savory rendition of the rare Sidra varietal.

Name: Green-Tip Geisha
Review: An impressive example of Mexico-grown Geisha: elegant, delicate, nuanced, and deeply engaging.

Name: Saint Helena Island Peaberry
Origin: Sandy Bay Valley, Saint Helena Island
Review: An extremely rare, limited-production coffee procured by Miguel Meza of Paradise Roasters, well worth sampling for its balanced, pleasingly complex cup profile.

Name: Philippines Sitio Naguey Natural
Review: A rare opportunity to sample a fine specialty coffee emerging valiantly from a neglected coffee-growing region where 90 percent of coffee grown is of the Robusta species and almost all is consumed locally.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Queen Honey
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: Deep, floral and cleanly fruit-toned, with prominent notes of dried stone fruit, spicy florals, and rich aromatic wood.

Name: Ethiopia Civet Sidama Papilio Natural
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A sweet-toned natural Ethiopia cup that supplements ripe berry notes and dark chocolate with inviting hints of rich sandalwood.

Name: Banco Gotete Ethiopia
Origin: Kochere Woreda, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Review: Fragrant jasmine and pungent incense-like notes in distinguish this crisply graceful wet-processed Ethiopia.

Name: Barichu Double
Review: A mesmerizing Kenya that is equally balanced among sweet, tart and savory impulses, with a particularly lively acidity.

Name: Papua New Guinea Timuza
Review: A friendly, engaging PNG cup with leading notes of deep florals supported by sweet nut tones throughout the profile.

Name: Rukera Kenya
Review: One of the most striking coffees we’ve tested this year: levitatingly vibrant, profoundly integrated, with savory and sweet in deep harmony — and, paradoxically, both classic and original in its expression of the great Kenya style.

Name: Colombia Pink Bourbon El Corazon
Review: A floral- and spice-toned cup: balanced, complex, multilayered.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela 1 Organic Natural Alaka
Origin: Hambela district, Oromia growing region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A pleasing Ethiopia natural: balanced, accessible, sweetly fruit-forward.

Name: Brazil Ibicoara Chapada Diamantina Natural
Origin: Ibicoara Municipality, Chapada Diamantina region, Bahia State, Brazil
Review: A solid Brazil natural: clean, deeply sweet, with a pleasing savory throughline.

Name: Costa Rica Coto Brus-La Amistad
Review: A friendly, easy-drinking Costa Rica cup, lively with citrusy herb notes and sweet florals.

Name: Karimikui AA Kenya
Review: A big, richly, authoritative sweet-savory Kenya, lifted and animated by shimmers of flowers and tart citrus.

Name: Peru Antonio Regalado Diaz El Huyacan La Palma
Review: An inviting coffee from Peru, characterized by deep florals and balanced by notes of stone fruit and citrus zest.

Name: Bella Carmona Guatemala
Review: Sweet and savory in equal measure, with a tart throughline: complex, nuanced, and multilayered.

Name: Peru Natural Jose Herrera Lot 21
Review: A heady coffee with clean, confident fruit notes throughout, supported by deep chocolate and spice-toned florals.

Name: Burundi Dukorerikawa Natural
Review: An attractively bright and fruit-centered coffee with unique and inviting savory elements.

Name: Single-Origin Colombian Medium Roast
Review: A highly portable, savory-leaning instant coffee with lingering notes of salty and sweet.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Sasaba
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A balanced, friendly natural-processed Ethiopia cup characterized by cocoa-toned stone fruit and delicate florals.

Name: Zambia Kateshi Natural Process
Review: A good choice for lovers of natural-processed coffees who prefer to avoid even a hint of sweet ferment; this cup is all clean fruit and florals.

Name: Ethiopia Gedeb Worka Sakaro
Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Review: A vibrant, high-toned washed-processed Ethiopia cup with rich floral and citrus tones throughout, all enveloped in dark chocolate.

Name: La Belleza Colombia
Review: An intriguing Colombia cup with deep savory-sweetness, top notes of elegant flowers and undertones of earthy-sweet pipe tobacco.

Name: Colombia Pink Bourbon
Review: A beautiful fruit- and floral-toned Colombia cup with undertones of rich chocolate and resonant sandalwood.

Name: Crystalina
Review: A lush, high-toned natural Colombia cup, as clean and bright as its name implies.

Name: Kenya Kiambu Gititu AA
Review: A classic Kenya cup: bright, balanced, sweetly savory and deeply vibrant throughout.

Name: Hawaiian Kona 100%
Origin: Kona growing district, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: A pretty, richly fruit-toned natural-processed Kona cup, organic-certified.

Name: La Palma Y El Tucan Hero Series Colombia Sidra Lot #190
Review: A uniquely compelling coffee that is, at turns, spicy, floral, chocolaty and fruit-toned, yet in the end harmonious and complete.

Name: Suyusama Colombia
Review: A deeply rich Colombia coffee with equal parts sweet (chocolate, flowers, fruit) and savory (hop flowers): balanced and inviting.

Name: ASOPCAFA Colombia
Review: Crisp, briskly dry yet sweet; delicately chocolate- and nut-toned.

Name: Natural Burundi Nemba
Review: A quietly original coffee: big-bodied, low-toned, crisply sweet-savory.

Name: Ka’u Champagne Natural
Origin: Ka'u growing region, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: Adventures in wine yeast: Two of Hawai’i’s (and the world’s) most common coffee varieties are elevated by an experimental fermentation method that results in a beverage that evokes Champagne — fruity but dry, not effervescent, but exceptionally vibrant.

Name: Monarch Gesha
Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai'i
Review: A deep, nuanced Gesha, excitingly original with high-toned herb notes, low-toned, almost candy-sweet fruit, and rich, spice-toned florals.

Name: Puna Barrel-Aged
Origin: Puna District, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: A fascinating sensory experience of a coffee aged in rum barrels: a recombinant mashup of musky fruit notes, sweet ferment, spicy florals, and chocolate with a salty edge.

Name: Kona Peaberry
Origin: Kona District, Kealakekua growing region, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: The classically delicate, subtle Kona Typica profile is enhanced by the careful medium roast, as well as by the selection of peaberries only.

Name: Laura’s Reserve SL-28
Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai'i
Review: A classic SL-28 cup, juicy-sweet with leading notes of red fruit and spice-toned sweet florals, supported by suggestions of buttery toffee.

Name: Ka’u Natural
Origin: Ka'u growing region, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: An engaging natural-processed Ka’u coffee, fruit-driven, with a foundation of pipe tobacco and cocoa notes.

Name: Maui Kupa’a Orange Bourbon
Review: A window into the great potential of higher-grown, cool-climate Maui coffee: bright but balanced, sweet-toned, and subtly nuanced. Grown in Kula, an agricultural zone on the western-facing slopes of Mount Haleakala and source of most of the island’s locally grown fruits and vegetables.

Name: Honey Typica
Origin: Ka'u growing region, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: Richly floral and cleanly fruit-toned, an impressive and increasingly familiar style of natural- and honey-processed coffee from Ka’u producers.

Name: Ka’u Typica Natural
Origin: Ka'u growing region, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: The fruit typical of a natural-processed coffee is pleasingly balanced here by deep nougat, citrus zest, and rich aromatic wood notes.

Name: Estate-Grown Mamo
Origin: Kealakekua, Kona growing district, Big Island of Hawai'i
Review: An opportunity to taste one of the world’s rarest coffees, a hybrid that exemplifies the persistence and ingenuity of coffee scientists.

Name: Colombian Supremo
Review: A deftly dark-roasted Colombia coffee with spicy florals, tropical fruit notes, and a deep molasses-like sweetness.

Name: Colombian Supremo
Review: A boldly dark-roasted Colombia coffee that accentuates chocolate and deep floral notes with a pretty throughline of cashew-like nut.

Name: Rwandan
Review: An intensely aromatic, roasty wood-framed cup with deep chocolate and savory floral notes.

Name: Colombia Las Joyas: Fidencio Martinez Lot
Review: An attractively tart and savory honey-processed coffee. Try it with salty morning dishes, which should develop its subtle, complementary sweetness.

Name: Colombia Tolima Monteverde Estate Natural Wush Wush
Review: An extraordinary coffee, difficult to characterize in typical coffee language, yet deeply satisfying, ringing with quiet, resonant authority.

Name: Ethiopia Oromia Guji Washed
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A deep, satisfying coffee, accessible yet resonantly complex.

Name: Yemen Matari
Review: A complex and engaging rendition of the characteristically richly spicy, tobacco-toned, floral-fruity Yemen profile.

Name: Kenya Murang’a Githiga AA
Review: Though delicate and perhaps a bit bright for some palates, the integrated breadth of “tart” is reminiscent of fine desserts by the same name. An elegant example of the Kenya type.

Name: Borneo Sabah Arabica
Review: The first coffee from Malaysian Borneo to be roasted for retail consumers in the U.S. and a promising new project in a region not yet known for specialty coffee.

Name: Colombia
Origin: Salgar Municipality, Antioquia Department, west-central Colombia
Review: A quietly seductive Colombia, organized around a pleasingly sweet chocolate note.

Name: D.R. Congo Muungano Co-Op
Origin: South Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Review: Deep, resonant and pleasing. Dry, yet quite plump and juicy.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Shantewene
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Review: A clean, bright natural Sidamo cup: high-toned fruit, deep musk notes, bittersweet complexity.

Name: Kivu Belt Lot 32 Rwanda
Review: A classic Rwanda cup: deeply sweet yet resonant with savory intrigue. Think cocoa-toned baking spices.

Name: Gesha Rebecca Natural
Review: A superbly structured natural-processed Ethiopia Gesha that leads with clean fruit tones supported by rich cocoa and deep florals.

Name: Easter Sunrise Blend
Review: A pleasing blend whose medium-dark roast profile brings out the coffee’s inherent cocoa tones.

Name: Tade GG Ethiopia Red Cherry
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Review: A classic Ethiopia cup: juicy-bright with leading notes of stone fruit and cocoa nib.

Name: Bufcafe Rwanda
Review: A quiet coffee with a very distinct savory sweetness. Those who avoid assertively bright coffees may enjoy its restraint.

Name: Café Granja La Esperanza Sudan Rume Natural
Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia
Review: A shape-shifter of a coffee: brilliant, original, absorbing.

Name: La Papaya Ecuador
Review: An aromatically bright and rousing Typica cup, high-toned with bittersweet citrus and rich spice notes.

Name: Aponte Colombia
Review: An attractive composite of tart and savory elements and an exciting coffee, given the historic limitations on processing in Colombia.

Name: Sumatra Tano Batak
Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia
Review: Classic Sumatra genius: chocolate and earth, sweet-savory berry, balanced and complete.

Name: Boru Batak Sumatra
Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia
Review: Fine traditional Sumatra, lightly plump and juicy in mouthfeel, aromatically driven by earth-nuanced pungent fruit and dry chocolate.

Name: Sumatra Gayo King Mandheling
Origin: Gayo (also Aceh) growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia
Review: Snacking after some work in the garden. The scent of fresh-turned earth and dark chocolate.

Name: Huta Raja Natural
